conversation.text: Hello would you like to learn how to make sherbet powder?
Yes what do I need to do first?
You need to get 500g of caster sugar, put it into a food processor and grind it for about 1 minute or until it's finely ground
evidence: Add 4 cups (500 g) of caster sugar to the bowl of a food processor.
Grind the sugar in a food processor.
Process the sugar for approximately 1 minute or until it is finely ground.

conversation.text: Ok. I have the caster sugar but don't have a food processor. What do I do?
If you have a spice or coffee grinder, you can use one of these instead.
evidence: If you don’t have a food processor, you can use a spice or coffee grinder.

conversation.text: Thanks. I have used a coffee grinder. What do I do next?
Is the sugar finely ground?
Yes it's finely ground
Great. Now mix in 10g of citric acid and 5 of baking soda to the mix until all blended up
evidence: Once you’ve ground the sugar, add 2 teaspoons (10 g) of food grade citric acid and 1 teaspoon (5 g) of baking soda to the food processor. Blend the mixture for another 30 seconds or until the ingredients are fully mixed.

conversation.text: Is baking soda the same as bicarbonate of soda?
Yes it's the same. Do you have this ingredient?
evidence: In some areas of the world, baking soda is also known as bicarbonate of soda.

conversation.text: Yes I do. I've mixed it all up.
Ok now transfer half of this powder mix to a separate bowl and set it aside.
evidence: pour half of the powder into a separate bowl. Set it aside for the moment.

conversation.text: Done. What is the next step?
With the mixture that's not in the bowl, you need to add and mix in 2 to 3 drops of lemon extract and a small amount of yellow gel food colouring.
evidence: ith half of the powder still in the food processor, add 2 to 3 drops of lemon extract and a small amount of yellow gel food coloring to the mixture. Blend it in the food processor again until it turns a light pastel yellow, and pour it into a clean bowl.

conversation.text: Ok what is next?
Is it a light pastel yellow colour?
Yes it is.
Now with the white powder in the other bowl, do the same but with raspberry flavouring (2 to 3 drops) and red food colouring (small amount). Mix it all together.
evidence: pour it into a clean bowl
Repeat the process with the remaining powder, raspberry flavoring, and red coloring

conversation.text: I think I have done this
Is it a pale pink colour?
Yes it is. What now?
Do you have 2 airtight containers available?
Yes. What do I need to do with them?
Put each coloured sherbet powder separately into each of the 2 containers for storage
evidence: pour them into airtight containers to store them
You should have a separate container for each flavor so they don’t get mixed together.

conversation.text: Done. is there anything else I need to do?
Nope. Now just enjoy the sherbet by dipping in a lollipop, wooden stick or even your fingers. It will stick once wet from licking them. How do they taste?
evidence: You can also use wooden popsicles sticks or plastic spoons to dip into the powder.
If you don’t mind getting dirty, you can also dip your fingers into the powder to eat it.

conversation.text: They are great. Thank you
Enjoy
Thank you. They are very nice

procedure.summary: Grind the sugar in a food processor.
procedure.description: Add 4 cups (500 g) of caster sugar to the bowl of a food processor. Process the sugar for approximately 1 minute or until it is finely ground. In some areas of the world, caster sugar is superfine or bar sugar. If you don’t have a food processor, you can use a spice or coffee grinder.

procedure.summary: Mix in the citric acid and baking soda.
procedure.description: Once you’ve ground the sugar, add 2 teaspoons (10 g) of food grade citric acid and 1 teaspoon (5 g) of baking soda to the food processor. Blend the mixture for another 30 seconds or until the ingredients are fully mixed. In some areas of the world, baking soda is also known as bicarbonate of soda.

procedure.summary: Transfer half of the powder to a bowl.
procedure.description: After the ingredients are fully blended, pour half of the powder into a separate bowl. Set it aside for the moment.

procedure.summary: Blend the lemon extract and yellow food coloring into the powder in the food processor.
procedure.description: With half of the powder still in the food processor, add 2 to 3 drops of lemon extract and a small amount of yellow gel food coloring to the mixture. Blend it in the food processor again until it turns a light pastel yellow, and pour it into a clean bowl. If you prefer, you can substitute orange extract for the lemon if you prefer. In that case, use orange gel food coloring to color the powder.

procedure.summary: Repeat the process with the remaining powder, raspberry flavoring, and red coloring.
procedure.description: After you’ve removed the lemon flavored powder from the food processor, clean out the bowl and return the other half of unflavored powder to it. Add 2 to 3 drops of raspberry flavoring and a small amount of red food coloring to the mixture. Blend it as you did with the lemon powder until it turns a pale pink. You can usually find raspberry flavoring in the baking aisle of the grocery store with the other flavor extracts.

procedure.summary: Transfer the sherbet powders to airtight containers for storage.
procedure.description: After you’ve mixed up both flavors of the sherbert powder, pour them into airtight containers to store them. You should have a separate container for each flavor so they don’t get mixed together. Sealable plastic bags work well for storing the sherbet powder.

procedure.summary: Dip lollipops into the powder to enjoy.
procedure.description: To eat the sherbet powder, suck on your favorite flavor of lollipop. Dip the pop into the powder so it sticks to the surface and lick it off. You can also use wooden popsicles sticks or plastic spoons to dip into the powder. If you don’t mind getting dirty, you can also dip your fingers into the powder to eat it.
